title: Paraneoplastic Neurological Syndrome
icd10: G13.1 (Other systemic atrophy primarily affecting CNS in neoplastic disease)
scope: ** Diagnosis, cancer screening, immunotherapy, and symptom management of paraneoplastic neurological syndromes. Includes antibody panels (intracellular and cell-surface), malignancy workup (CT, PET-CT, organ-specific imaging), first-line immunotherapy (IV methylprednisolone, IVIG, PLEX), second-line immunosuppression (rituximab, cyclophosphamide), tumor-directed therapy coordination, and long-term monitoring. Covers key clinical phenotypes: limbic encephalitis, cerebellar degeneration, sensory neuropathy, opsoclonus-myoclonus, encephalomyelitis, and neuromuscular junction disorders. For autoimmune encephalitis with predominantly cell-surface antibodies (anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2), use "Autoimmune Encephalitis" template. For myasthenia gravis, use "Myasthenia Gravis" template. For Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, use dedicated LEMS template when available.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen; cytopenias from occult malignancy
Metabolic screen; hepatic/renal function for immunotherapy; electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia in SIADH)
Inflammatory marker; elevated in malignancy and autoimmune conditions
Infection screen; systemic inflammation
Thyroid dysfunction as alternative etiology for encephalopathy or neuropathy
Metabolic encephalopathy screen; pre-steroid baseline
Glycemic status before high-dose steroids; diabetic neuropathy differential
Tumor marker; hemolysis screen; elevated in many malignancies
Seizure threshold; neuromuscular function
Metabolic screen; weakness differential
Coagulopathy screen pre-LP; DIC from malignancy
UTI as encephalopathy trigger; exclude infection before immunotherapy
Rule out septic encephalopathy before immunotherapy
Sepsis screen; metabolic screen
Distinguish bacterial infection from paraneoplastic inflammation
Hepatic encephalopathy mimic
Toxic encephalopathy mimic
Teratogenicity of immunosuppressants; imaging planning
Cardiac involvement; autonomic instability assessment
Myositis (dermatomyositis overlap); seizure-related rhabdomyolysis
Tumor lysis risk if malignancy identified

Paraneoplastic Antibody Panel.rationale: Most common intracellular antibody; associated with SCLC (>90%); encephalomyelitis, sensory neuropathy, cerebellar degeneration, autonomic neuropathy
Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration; associated with ovarian cancer, breast cancer
Opsoclonus-myoclonus; brainstem encephalitis; associated with breast cancer, SCLC
Encephalomyelitis, cerebellar degeneration, chorea, neuropathy, optic neuritis; associated with SCLC, thymoma
Stiff-person syndrome; encephalomyelitis; associated with breast cancer, SCLC
Limbic/diencephalic encephalitis; hypothalamic dysfunction; associated with testicular germ cell tumor (young males), lung cancer (older patients)
Lambert-Eaton overlap; SCLC marker; cerebellar degeneration
Brainstem/cerebellar syndrome; associated with testicular seminoma
Cell-surface; paraneoplastic with ovarian teratoma (young females); limbic encephalitis
Cell-surface; limbic encephalitis; faciobrachial dystonic seizures; associated with thymoma (~5-10%)
Cell-surface; limbic encephalitis; Morvan syndrome; neuromyotonia; associated with thymoma (~20-30%)
Cell-surface; limbic encephalitis with seizures; 50% associated with SCLC
Cell-surface; limbic encephalitis; associated with thymoma, lung, breast cancer
High titers (>20 nmol/L): stiff-person, limbic encephalitis, cerebellar ataxia; low titers non-specific
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (P/Q-type); cerebellar degeneration; ~60% LEMS cases associated with SCLC
Comprehensive panel: ANNA-1, ANNA-2, PCA-1, PCA-2, PCA-Tr, amphiphysin, CV2, GAD65, VGCC
CSF panel: ANNA-1, ANNA-2, PCA-1, amphiphysin, CV2, GAD65
Connective tissue disease with neurological involvement
Baseline before immunotherapy; IgA deficiency (IVIG contraindication)
Paraproteinemia-associated neuropathy; myeloma

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Cerebellar degeneration; neuropathy; associated with SCLC
Cerebellar degeneration; associated with Hodgkin lymphoma
Progressive encephalomyelitis with rigidity and myoclonus (PERM)
Encephalitis with hyperexcitability and GI symptoms
Prion disease mimic in rapidly progressive cerebellar degeneration
If standard panels negative and clinical suspicion remains high

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Tumor markers: AFP, beta-hCG, CA-125, CA 19-9, CEA, PSA
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Adjunctive tumor screening (not diagnostic alone); AFP/beta-hCG for germ cell tumors; CA-125 for ovarian

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Mildly elevated in paraneoplastic; markedly elevated suggests carcinomatous meningitis or GBS
Low glucose suggests carcinomatous meningitis or infection
Rule out HSV encephalitis (limbic encephalitis mimic)
Intrathecal IgG synthesis; supports CNS inflammation
ANNA-1, ANNA-2, PCA-1, amphiphysin, CV2, GAD65, NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2 -- CBA method
Prion disease mimic in rapidly progressive cerebellar syndrome

Essential/First-line.target: Rule out mass, hemorrhage, hydrocephalus, brain metastases

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.target: Mesial temporal T2/FLAIR hyperintensity (limbic encephalitis); cerebellar atrophy (subacute cerebellar degeneration); leptomeningeal enhancement; brain metastases
Lung mass (SCLC, NSCLC); mediastinal mass (thymoma); hilar adenopathy
Ovarian mass, renal cell carcinoma, hepatic metastases, retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy

Extended.timing: Within 1-2 weeks; STAT if CT negative and high clinical suspicion
Extended.target: Occult malignancy not identified on CT; FDG-avid tumor; most sensitive modality for cancer screening in PNS
Testicular germ cell tumor (anti-Ma2, KLHL11); testicular seminoma

Extended.item: MRI spine with and without contrast (CPT 72156)
Extended.target: Myelitis; radiculitis; cord compression from metastatic disease; cauda equina involvement
Sensory neuronopathy pattern (non-length-dependent, asymmetric); sensorimotor neuropathy; neuromuscular junction defect (LEMS: low CMAP, incremental response on RNS); myopathy
Focal/generalized slowing; epileptiform discharges; subclinical seizures

Rare/Specialized.target: Cerebellar hypermetabolism (early) or hypometabolism (late); mesial temporal metabolic changes
Decremental response at 3 Hz (MG); incremental response >100% at 50 Hz or post-exercise (LEMS)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If indicated by age/symptoms or specific antibody profile

Rare/Specialized.target: REM sleep behavior disorder; narcolepsy-like phenotype (anti-Ma2)

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line immunotherapy for acute paraneoplastic neurological syndrome; reduces CNS inflammation

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; infuse over 1-2 hours

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; psychosis from steroids
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h (target <180); BP; mood/sleep; I/O; GI prophylaxis

Acute/Emergent.indication: Stress ulcer prevention during high-dose corticosteroids

doseOptions.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 40 mg IV/PO

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily during steroid course and taper
dosing.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 40 mg IV/PO

doseOptions.orderSentence: Insulin sliding scale Per protocol SC

dosing.instructions: Per institutional sliding scale protocol if glucose >180 mg/dL
dosing.orderSentence: Insulin sliding scale Per protocol SC

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line immunotherapy; antibody-mediated mechanism; given concurrently or sequentially with IV steroids

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day IV x 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse per weight-based protocol; premedicate with acetaminophen, diphenhydramine

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk); recent thromboembolic event; renal failure
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function daily; headache (aseptic meningitis); thrombosis; volume overload; check IgA level before first dose

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line immunotherapy; removes pathogenic antibodies; preferred for cell-surface antibody syndromes

dosing.instructions: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; albumin replacement preferred

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability; sepsis; coagulopathy; poor vascular access
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP during exchanges; electrolytes (Ca, K, Mg); coagulation (fibrinogen); line site; citrate reactions

Acute/Emergent.indication: Seizure management in paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory status; sedation level; airway patency

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure management in paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis; preferred first-line ASM

dosing.instructions: Load: 1000-1500 mg IV; Maintenance: 500 mg BID, titrate to 1000-1500 mg BID; max 3000 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Behavioral changes (rage, irritability); suicidality; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Second-line ASM for seizures; favorable drug interaction profile with immunotherapy

dosing.instructions: Load: 200-400 mg IV; Maintenance: 100 mg BID, titrate to 200 mg BID; max 400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Second/third degree AV block; severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG (PR prolongation); dizziness; cardiac monitoring during load

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain from paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d; max 3600 mg/day divided TID

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; respiratory depression (with opioids)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain from paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy; alternative to gabapentin

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase q1wk to 150-300 mg BID; max 600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment (adjust per CrCl); angioedema history
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; weight gain; peripheral edema

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg BID; titrate by 0.5 mg q3d; max 6 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; acute narrow-angle glaucoma; respiratory depression

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Vertigo and vestibular symptoms from cerebellar involvement

dosing.instructions: 25 mg PO q8h PRN vertigo; max 75 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Concurrent anticholinergic use; urinary retention; glaucoma

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea/vomiting from cerebellar involvement or brainstem dysfunction

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain; insomnia from paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg qHS; titrate by 10-25 mg q1-2wk; max 150 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; glaucoma; elderly
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects; QTc monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Stiffness/spasticity from paraneoplastic stiff-person spectrum or myelopathy

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; titrate by 5 mg/dose q3d; max 80 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment; abrupt withdrawal risk (seizures, hallucinations)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; weakness; hepatic function; do NOT stop abruptly

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Stiff-person spectrum; muscle spasms; paraneoplastic rigidity

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg BID; titrate to effect; max 40 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression; myasthenia gravis; acute narrow-angle glaucoma

dosing.instructions: Start 3 mg qHS; may increase to 5-10 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sleep quality; no significant drug interactions

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Depression and anxiety associated with chronic paraneoplastic neurological syndrome

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q1-2wk; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring; hyponatremia (SIADH); GI side effects

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Second-line immunotherapy for refractory paraneoplastic syndrome; B-cell depletion; more effective for cell-surface antibody syndromes

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m2 IV weekly x 4 doses OR 1000 mg IV x 2 doses (day 0 and day 14); premedicate with methylprednisolone 100 mg, acetaminophen, diphenhydramine

Second-Line/Refractory.contraindications: Active hepatitis B; severe active infection; live vaccines within 4 weeks
Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: Hepatitis B serology (before first dose); CBC q2-4 weeks; immunoglobulin levels q3 months; CD19/CD20 B-cell counts; infusion reactions; PML surveillance

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Second-line immunotherapy for refractory paraneoplastic syndrome; used for intracellular antibody syndromes unresponsive to first-line

dosing.instructions: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly x 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA (uroprotection)

Second-Line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy; active infection; bone marrow failure; bladder outlet obstruction
Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC weekly x 4 weeks after each cycle (nadir day 10-14); urinalysis; BMP; LFTs; fertility counseling; hemorrhagic cystitis prevention

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Transition from IV methylprednisolone; sustained immunosuppression during tumor workup

dosing.instructions: 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) x 2 weeks; taper by 10 mg/week to 20 mg; then by 5 mg/week to discontinuation or low-dose maintenance

Second-Line/Refractory.contraindications: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; avascular necrosis
Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: Glucose; BP; bone density if prolonged; mood; weight; adrenal insufficiency on taper

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Maintenance immunotherapy for partially responsive paraneoplastic syndrome

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days (repeat q4 weeks) or 1 g/kg x 2 days q4 weeks

Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: Renal function; headache; IgG trough levels; infusion reactions

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Maintenance plasmapheresis for partially responsive paraneoplastic syndrome

doseOptions.orderSentence: Repeated PLEX cycles 1-1.5 plasma volumes IV

dosing.instructions: 5 exchanges (repeat q4-6 weeks as needed); 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; albumin replacement preferred
dosing.orderSentence: Repeated PLEX cycles 1-1.5 plasma volumes IV

Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: BP during exchanges; electrolytes (Ca, K, Mg); coagulation (fibrinogen); line site; citrate reactions

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Third-line immunotherapy for refractory cases; IL-6 receptor blockade

dosing.instructions: 8 mg/kg IV every 4 weeks (max 800 mg/dose)

Second-Line/Refractory.contraindications: Active infection; hepatic impairment (ALT >5x ULN); diverticulitis; concurrent live vaccines
Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, lipids q4-8 weeks; infection surveillance; GI perforation risk; neutropenia

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.indication: Long-term immunosuppression for relapse prevention in cell-surface antibody paraneoplastic syndromes

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg IV every 6 months; re-dose based on CD19/CD20 B-cell repopulation or clinical relapse

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.pretreatment: Hepatitis B/C serology; quantitative immunoglobulins; CBC; LFTs; chest X-ray; TB screening (QuantiFERON); vaccinations current (no live vaccines within 4 weeks)
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.contraindications: Active hepatitis B; severe active infection; live vaccines within 4 weeks; severe hypogammaglobulinemia (IgG <300)
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.monitoring: CD19/CD20 counts q3 months; immunoglobulin levels q3-6 months; hepatitis B surveillance; infection monitoring; PML surveillance; CBC q3 months

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.indication: Steroid-sparing immunosuppression for maintenance; prevents relapse

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase to 1000 mg PO BID over 2-4 weeks; target 1500-3000 mg/day

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.pretreatment: CBC; LFTs; pregnancy test (females); contraception plan
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.monitoring: CBC q2 weeks x 3 months, then monthly; LFTs; GI symptoms; infection surveillance; pregnancy prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg PO daily; increase by 50 mg every 2 weeks to target 2-3 mg/kg/day

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.pretreatment: TPMT genotype/activity (mandatory before starting); CBC; LFTs
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.contraindications: TPMT deficiency (myelosuppression risk); pregnancy (relative); concurrent allopurinol (reduce dose by 75%)
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.monitoring: TPMT genotype before starting; CBC q2 weeks x 2 months, then monthly; LFTs; pancreatitis; infection surveillance

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.indication: Low-dose maintenance immunosuppression while steroid-sparing agent reaches full effect

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg PO daily; aim to taper off within 3-6 months if on steroid-sparing agent

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.pretreatment: Baseline glucose; BP; DEXA if anticipated use >3 months
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.contraindications: Poorly controlled diabetes; active infection; avascular necrosis
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.monitoring: Glucose; BP; bone density (DEXA if >3 months); weight; mood; cataracts; adrenal assessment on taper

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.indication: Maintenance immunotherapy for partially responsive paraneoplastic syndrome; especially cell-surface antibody syndromes

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg IV every 4 weeks OR 1 g/kg IV every 4-6 weeks; adjust per response

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.pretreatment: IgA level; renal function; CBC; coagulation screen
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.contraindications: IgA deficiency; thromboembolic history; renal failure
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.monitoring: Renal function; headache; IgG trough levels; infusion reactions; thrombosis surveillance

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.indication: Osteoporosis prevention during prolonged steroid use

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D (bone protection) 1000-1200 mg calcium + 1000-2000 IU vitamin D PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg/day + Vitamin D 1000-2000 IU/day
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D (bone protection) 1000-1200 mg calcium + 1000-2000 IU vitamin D PO

Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.pretreatment: 25-OH Vitamin D level; calcium level; DEXA baseline if steroid use >3 months
Disease-Modifying / Long-Term Immunosupp.monitoring: 25-OH Vitamin D level; calcium; DEXA q1-2 years

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology/neuro-oncology) consult for diagnosis confirmation, antibody interpretation, immunotherapy guidance, and longitudinal care
Oncology consult for tumor identification, staging, and treatment planning (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation)
Gynecologic oncology referral for ovarian teratoma screening and resection in females with anti-NMDAR or anti-Yo antibodies
Urology referral for testicular ultrasound and germ cell tumor evaluation in males <50 with anti-Ma2 or anti-KLHL11 antibodies
Pulmonology consult for respiratory function monitoring and ventilator management in cases with respiratory failure
Hematology/apheresis service for PLEX coordination and vascular access
Epilepsy/EEG service for seizure management and continuous EEG monitoring in limbic encephalitis
Psychiatry consult for behavioral/psychiatric manifestations and medication management in paraneoplastic encephalitis
Physical therapy for gait training, balance rehabilitation, and fall prevention in cerebellar degeneration and sensory neuropathy
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive strategies, and upper extremity coordination training
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation, language rehabilitation, and cognitive-linguistic therapy in encephalitis cases
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive assessment, rehabilitation planning, and serial monitoring
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line and second-line agents
Social work for family support, insurance navigation, disability resources, and long-term care planning
Palliative care for refractory cases, symptom management, and goals of care discussion in progressive intracellular antibody syndromes
Rehabilitation medicine for comprehensive inpatient or outpatient rehab program coordination
Endocrinology for steroid-induced hyperglycemia management and hypothalamic dysfunction in anti-Ma2 cases
Ophthalmology for visual symptom evaluation, cancer-associated retinopathy screening, and optic neuritis assessment

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new seizures, sudden behavioral changes, worsening weakness, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness (may indicate disease progression or autonomic crisis)
Paraneoplastic neurological syndrome is caused by the immune system attacking the nervous system in response to an underlying cancer -- treating the cancer is the most important step in treatment

Neurological recovery depends on antibody type: cell-surface antibody syndromes often improve with treatment; intracellular antibody syndromes may have limited neurological recovery despite tumor treatment
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology due to risk of seizures, cerebellar dysfunction, or cognitive impairment
Report any signs of infection (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash) immediately while on immunotherapy as immune suppression increases infection risk
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy; inform all healthcare providers of immunosuppression status
Do not stop anti-seizure medications abruptly (risk of rebound seizures)
Keep a symptom diary documenting neurological changes, seizure frequency, and functional status to track treatment response
Cancer screening follow-up appointments are critical -- repeat imaging every 6 months for at least 2 years if initial tumor screen is negative
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs (lower seizure threshold, interact with medications, and may mask neurological changes)
Pregnancy must be avoided during immunotherapy; discuss contraception with neurology and OB/GYN
Fall prevention measures at home (remove throw rugs, install grab bars, adequate lighting) due to cerebellar ataxia and sensory neuropathy
Medical alert bracelet recommended (paraneoplastic syndrome, seizure risk, immunosuppressed)
Cognitive rehabilitation exercises as directed by occupational therapy and neuropsychology

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to reduce lung cancer risk and improve overall oncologic outcomes
Low-sodium diet to reduce fluid retention on corticosteroids and manage steroid-induced hypertension
Low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary bike, seated exercises) to maintain strength and cardiovascular fitness within functional limitations
Energy conservation with scheduled rest periods to manage cancer-related and treatment-related fatigue
Aspiration precautions including modified diet texture and supervised meals if bulbar dysfunction present
Frequent repositioning every 2 hours to prevent pressure ulcers during immobility
Calcium and vitamin D supplementation for bone protection during prolonged corticosteroid use
Nutritional optimization with dietitian consultation to maintain weight and support immune function during treatment
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards and install assistive devices for cerebellar ataxia and peripheral neuropathy
CPAP compliance if obstructive sleep apnea identified during evaluation to prevent nocturnal hypoxia

differential.features: Cell-surface antibody positive but no tumor found; younger patients; prodromal illness
differential.tests: Full antibody panel; comprehensive tumor screening; PET-CT; repeat imaging if initially negative

differential.features: Progressive encephalopathy, periventricular enhancing mass, immunocompromised
differential.tests: CSF cytology/flow cytometry; FDG-PET; brain biopsy; EBV PCR in CSF

differential.features: Known primary cancer; ring-enhancing lesions on MRI; often multifocal
differential.tests: Contrast-enhanced MRI brain; CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; biopsy if needed

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; radiculopathy; CSF with low glucose, high protein, positive cytology
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3 if initially negative); gadolinium-enhanced MRI brain and spine

differential.features: Rapidly progressive dementia; myoclonus; cortical ribboning on DWI; periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG
differential.tests: 14-3-3; RT-QuIC; MRI DWI cortical ribboning; EEG periodic discharges

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting course; typical MRI lesion distribution (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial)
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine; oligoclonal bands; McDonald criteria

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; hypothalamic dysfunction; leptomeningeal enhancement; hilar adenopathy
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT; biopsy (non-caseating granulomas)

differential.features: Headache; stroke-like episodes; multifocal infarcts; elevated inflammatory markers
Acute fever; temporal lobe involvement (HSV); CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: HSV PCR; VZV PCR; specific viral serologies

differential.features: Encephalopathy with very high anti-TPO; steroid-responsive; no tumor
differential.tests: Anti-TPO; anti-thyroglobulin; dramatic steroid response; negative tumor screen

differential.features: Cognitive decline; psychiatric symptoms; Argyll Robertson pupils
Subacute combined degeneration; posterior column dysfunction; megaloblastic anemia
differential.tests: B12 level; methylmalonic acid; MRI spine (dorsal column signal)

differential.features: Temporal correlation with exposure; length-dependent pattern
Proximal weakness; autonomic dysfunction; facilitation on repetitive nerve stimulation
differential.tests: Anti-VGCC antibodies; RNS with incremental response; CT chest for SCLC

differential.features: Fatigable weakness; ptosis; diplopia; decrement on RNS
Family history; slowly progressive; genetic testing

evidence.recommendation: Updated diagnostic criteria for paraneoplastic neurological syndromes (PNS-Care 2021)
evidence.source: [Graus F et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2021;92:1135-1145](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34083404/)

evidence.recommendation: Classical paraneoplastic antibodies: anti-Hu, anti-Yo, anti-Ri, anti-CV2, anti-amphiphysin
Cell-surface antibodies more treatment-responsive than intracellular antibodies
evidence.source: [Dalmau J & Graus F. N Engl J Med 2018;378:840-851](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29490181/)

evidence.recommendation: Anti-Hu syndrome: encephalomyelitis and SCLC association
Anti-Yo paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration and gynecologic cancer
Anti-Ri opsoclonus-myoclonus and breast cancer
Anti-CV2/CRMP5 neuropathy and SCLC
Anti-Ma2 limbic encephalitis and testicular germ cell tumor
Anti-VGCC and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome with SCLC
evidence.source: [Titulaer MJ et al. J Clin Oncol 2011;29:902-908](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21245427/)

evidence.recommendation: LEMS DELTA-P score for SCLC prediction
FDG-PET/CT superior to CT for occult tumor detection in PNS
Repeat tumor screening q6 months for 2+ years if initial screen negative
evidence.source: [Graus F et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34083404/)

evidence.recommendation: First-line immunotherapy: IV steroids, IVIG, PLEX
evidence.source: [Rosenfeld MR & Dalmau J. Curr Treat Options Neurol 2003;5:69-77](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12521565/)

evidence.recommendation: Tumor treatment improves neurological outcome
Rituximab for refractory paraneoplastic syndromes
Cyclophosphamide for intracellular antibody syndromes
evidence.source: [Dalmau J & Graus F. N Engl J Med 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29490181/)

evidence.recommendation: Poor neurological prognosis with intracellular antibodies despite treatment
Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration: irreversible Purkinje cell loss
Anti-SOX1 as SCLC marker
Anti-KLHL11 and testicular seminoma
evidence.source: [Mandel-Brehm C et al. N Engl J Med 2019;381:47-56](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31269365/)

evidence.recommendation: Levetiracetam as preferred ASM in autoimmune/paraneoplastic seizures
Subacute sensory neuronopathy (Denny-Brown syndrome)
evidence.source: [Camdessanche JP et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2002;73:179-183](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12122178/)

evidence.recommendation: Paraneoplastic opsoclonus-myoclonus in adults
Ovarian teratoma resection improves anti-NMDAR outcomes
GABA-B encephalitis and SCLC association (~50%)
Comprehensive review of paraneoplastic neurological syndromes
evidence.source: [Dalmau J & Graus F. N Engl J Med 2018;378:840-851](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29490181/)

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (mental status, cranial nerves, cerebellar testing, motor, sensory, reflexes)
monitoring.action: If worsening: urgent re-imaging; escalate immunotherapy; consider ICU transfer
Document trajectory; guide treatment escalation
Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250
Autonomic dysregulation treatment per protocol
Treat autonomic instability; cardiology consult if sustained arrhythmia
Rule out infection; cooling measures if central hyperthermia

monitoring.item: Respiratory function (RR, SpO2, NIF if neuromuscular)
monitoring.action: NIF worsening: intubation threshold; ICU transfer
Escalate ASMs; continuous EEG; re-assess immunotherapy
Correct per protocol; fluid restriction if SIADH
Hold IVIG if Cr rising; hydration; nephrology consult
Hold immunotherapy if critically low; growth factor support
Dose adjustment or hold hepatotoxic medications
Hold PLEX if <100; FFP replacement
Adjust fluids; diuretics if fluid overload

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (cognition, cerebellar function, sensory, motor, gait)
monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 6 months; then q3 months x 2 years; then q6 months
monitoring.action: If worsening: repeat antibody titers; re-image for tumor; escalate immunotherapy
Document trajectory; adjust rehabilitation goals

monitoring.item: Tumor surveillance imaging (CT or PET-CT per antibody protocol)
monitoring.frequency: q6 months x 2 years if initial tumor screen negative; annually thereafter x 2 more years
monitoring.action: If tumor found: urgent oncology referral and surgical resection

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months x 2 years; then annually
monitoring.action: Rising titers may precede clinical relapse or new tumor; increase surveillance

monitoring.item: MRI brain with and without contrast
monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-treatment; then annually x 3 years
monitoring.action: New/worsening lesions: relapse workup; repeat antibody testing

monitoring.frequency: Q2-4 weeks on mycophenolate/azathioprine; then monthly; q3 months on rituximab
monitoring.action: Hold/reduce immunosuppression; growth factor support

monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 3 months on azathioprine/mycophenolate; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Dose reduction or switch agent
Immunoglobulin replacement if recurrent infections with hypogammaglobulinemia
Guide re-dosing interval

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if steroids >3 months; repeat q1-2 years
monitoring.action: Bisphosphonate therapy; calcium/vitamin D optimization
Guide cognitive rehabilitation; inform return to work planning
Worsening suggests ongoing neuronal damage; escalate treatment
Adjust ASMs; consider repeat immunotherapy if worsening
Adjust dose; assess adherence

disposition.criteria: Stable or improving neurological examination; no active seizures; able to perform basic ADLs safely; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; outpatient infusion arranged if needed; family/caregiver education completed; no significant autonomic instability; tumor workup initiated or completed

New-onset paraneoplastic syndrome requiring expedited workup; immunotherapy initiation (IV steroids, IVIG); seizures requiring medication adjustment; moderate functional impairment; active tumor screening and biopsy coordination

Severe autonomic instability (hemodynamic swings, arrhythmias); respiratory failure requiring ventilatory support; refractory status epilepticus; altered consciousness (GCS <12); severe encephalitis requiring continuous EEG; rapidly progressive neurological decline

PLEX or continuous EEG not available; neuroimmunology or neuro-oncology specialist not available; need for tumor resection at specialized center; requires ICU capabilities not available at current facility

Medically stable; significant functional deficits (cerebellar ataxia, sensory neuropathy, cognitive impairment) requiring intensive therapy; unable to safely return home; expected to benefit from structured rehabilitation

All patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; oncology follow-up per tumor type; infusion center for maintenance immunotherapy; neuropsychology referral; rehabilitation services; tumor surveillance per antibody protocol (Section 4C equivalent)

New or worsening seizures; behavioral/cognitive regression; fever or signs of infection on immunotherapy; suspected relapse (any new neurological symptoms); newly identified tumor requiring urgent intervention
